awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Intelligent Flight Planning of Multiple Drones for Power Line Inspection
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to enable automated and simultaneous inspection by multiple drones. Potential customers include electric utility companies, public safety organizations, and drone operators. The benefits of efficient drone-based inspection of electric power lines include greater safety for linemen, cost savings for maintenance inspections (e.g., to detect vegetation near power lines), and substantial time savings. The ability to utilize multiple drones to reduce the inspection time can be critical when assessing damage and recovering from outages due to storms and hurricanes. The advantage of using a team of drones is that multiple power lines can be simultaneously inspected, thus parallelizing the inspection process and substantially reducing the mission time for the human operators.  The team will partner with drone operators and electric utilities to perform a proof-of-concept distribution line inspection and to evaluate the effectiveness of the approach.  There is also potential for applying the proposed software to the transportation and energy industries for inspection of highways, railroads, and oil and gas pipelines. The project team will work with the technology commercialization arm of the university and will discover additional potential partners.

The proposed project will develop, implement, and validate flight planning algorithms and software for a team of drones to efficiently inspect power lines. Given the geographic locations of the power transmission and distribution lines, and the number and model of the drones, the drone routing algorithms will automatically generate flight plans for each of the drones from their home locations. A key research challenge that will be addressed is the development of efficient algorithms capable of scaling up to handle dense power line networks over large areas. The ability to automatically assign and coordinate multiple drones, with battery constraints and potentially even of different types, to different sections of the power lines in a resource-optimal manner will be a significant advance over the current state of the art in both manual and drone based inspection.  To enable ease of use for commercialization, the software will run in the cloud, enabling workers in the field to obtain automatically generated flight plans from their smartphones.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project developed efficient and scalable algorithms for intelligent routing of multiple robots (e.g., unmanned aerial vehicles or drones) to perform automated inspection of linear infrastructure such as electric power lines and road networks. These enable parallel deployment of teams of robots to inspect infrastructure. Importantly, these algorithms consider direction-dependent costs and resource demands (e.g., flying upwind may require more time and energy than flying downwind), and provide resource-aware solutions (e.g., routes that satisfy UAV battery life constraints).

For inspection of linear infrastructure, which we call the line coverage problem, three types of algorithms were developed: (1) A fast heuristic algorithm, Merge-Embed-Merge, for line coverage by multiple robots with resource constraints (e.g., battery life limits). (2) An optimal mixed integer linear programming formulation that provides the optimal solution for multiple robot line coverage, but potentially can take time exponential in the size of network. (3) An approximation algorithm for line coverage by a single robot without resource constraints, which provides performance guarantees on the quality of the generated solutions.

The Merge-Embed-Merge algorithm has been generalized to generate solutions for robots with nonholonomic constraints (e.g., fixed-wing unmanned aerial vehicles) and solutions that consider environmental conditions (e.g., wind speed and direction). The implemented software has been designed for deployment in the cloud, thus making it possible for drone operators in the field to download automatically generated flight plans for their drones.

Through I-Corps interviews, we identified a need for efficient area coverage algorithms for multiple robots, and generalized the line coverage algorithms to address this need. These algorithms can now generate efficient motion plans for a team of robots to inspect an area while taking resource constraints into account. We have also developed sensor placement algorithms for environmental monitoring, and prioritized exploration algorithms for robots to compute building layouts in time-critical and dangerous environments.

PhD students working on the project have presented their research at international conferences, gained experience in discussing their work with industry experts, and have mentored Masters and Bachelors students in research. Undergraduate students, supported as REUs, worked on software and hardware implementations of the developed algorithms.

To facilitate technology transfer and enable dissemination of the developed algorithms, we have released open source software for the algorithms and datasets on GitHub. These include the line coverage library, the area coverage library, and software for gas leak rate estimation. We have also provided routing solutions for line and area coverage to companies and government agencies for evaluation. Several papers describing our work have been published at leading conferences and journals. This research was disseminated through courses at UNC Charlotte, research presentations at international conferences, industry tech transfer events, videos on YouTube, and outreach activities at science museums.


Last Modified: 11/24/2023
Modified by: Srinivas Akella
